The rowers themselves would have all been likewise lost, if nature instructing them to repell force by force, they had not by swimming preserved themselves. But Parisius unacquainted with that art, soon perisht in the waters.

The report of that disaster being carried on the wings of the wind, which had raised the tempest, immediatly arrived at the ears of his Parents. Whereupon his father hastning with all speed to the shore, caused some fishermen to search for the body of his son. Every one may imagine how he grieved in the mean time, and wept, especially when he saw for along time together, they could not finde the body. O God! To what disastrous tryals of affection, is a father often subject, and reserved. The carkass being found in the end, 'tis compassion to conceal the afflictions of the mother.

He had been kept a day, and a night in the house, and beginning now to putrifie; the Priests and the Friars were come to convey him to the grave, when his divout mother, who had never ceased weeping and praying, renewed her tears, and prayers to the Saint, and so passionately and earnestly besought him (promising if he reviv'd to make him a Fryar of his Seraphical Order) that he mov'd by her tears, obtain'd his life of God, causing him in the presence of many standers by to rise and live again.

So Parisius restored to the light of the World, when he was of an age to perform his mothers vow, took the habit of St. Francis, and in a sacred Cloyster living vertuously, and exemplarily, dyed many years after very holily there.

div.head: The Fourt Chapter.
div.p:
THere is no greater wonder to me, then to consider, that a Gentleman in an eminent condition, is as subject to mortality as the meanest, and most miserable person. He is borne great and noble, though 'tis not his merit, but good luck, to be born so, and swadled in cloaths, which for beauty, and value may contend
with Heavens zones, no sooner begins to cry out in his cradle, but many Servants waiting upon him, stand ready about him, to remove all disturbance, and annoyance from him.

Then brought up with qualities, which are so rare, and exquisite, they pretend not as it were, to be Earthly, he arrives not at the years of understanding & reason, but seeing among other humble houses, his own, like a Gyant, obtain the name of a Pallace, and beholding the walls cloath'd with proud and stately hangings (but the Churches, of God unfurnisht and bare) and minding onely household-stuffe, plate, attendance, obsequiousness, and the homages of all he beholds, he thinks himself divine and immortall.

With a high, and lofty forehead, a proud look and haughty behaviour, he disdains to cast his eyes on the Earth, being affraid with an humble aspect, to prejudice, and diminish the nobility he boasts of. Now if he should be askt, if his skin and flesh be penetrable, and subject to corruption, his blood red like others, and he lyable to passions, to anguish, diseases, and miseries, as the vilest of Creatures, what answer could he possibly give? Is it not a madness worthy
of laughter, like that of Democritus, to see, that a Man, who differs not from the poor in the manner of his birth & his sorrows, and hath as much need of air to breath in, of light to look about him, of meat to sustain him, and cloath to apparrell him, as the greatest beggar living, whose wit, and whose senses are equall, and often inferiour to the despicablest person, because he differs from him in fortune (then which there is nothing more instable, and more transitory) should be so farr above him in his thoughts, as to scorn to converse with him? Since therefore 'tis a truth, that the greatest persons living are subject to miseries, it will not be strange, that Aldonza the Infanta of Portugall was sick.
The Heiress of that Kingdom, and delight of her Parents, had afflicted all with her malady, and forc't the eyes of all to bewail her infirmity.

How could a disease invade those royal lodgings, where Men, because fained, do serve instead of Tapistries, and Tapistries, because ply able, shew how Men should live in Courts? Could not the cloth of State, with that Majestick pompe, preserve her in health, whom the titles of Highness and Serenity, do tickle with a seeming immortality?

Now the sickness of the Infanta Aldonza being so much the more grievous, because the more unknown, the famousest Physitians of Europe were sent for to Lisbone, who tormenting her with severall medicines, instead of assisting her, did her very much harm. She therefore consuming by little and little, being equally deprived of hope, and remedy, shewed the ruines and decay of that beauty, which had made her seem an Angel to all that beheld her. But the flesh being gone from her cheeks, which before were fresh, and flourishing Aprills of humanity, and the lustre of her eyes, from which the Stars acknowledged their brightness, grown dim, and obscur'd, she lookt like a skeleton cover'd over with skin, and consuming made a tombe for her self of her bones. Whereupon if her Parents wept much, and particularly the Queen was dying every minute of grief, 'tis as easie to believe, as probable to imagine.

But they with the rest of the Court, had their sorrow encreased, when the Infanta very weak, exhausted, and fainting, was little less then dead. Then Teresa (for so the Queen her Mother was call'd) growing strong by despair, kneel'd
down on the ground, and lifting up her eyes towards Heaven, said thus.

St. Anthony, who in so many parts of the World, both in life, and in death, hast assisted, afflicted and disconsolate persons, comfort me now, who, while thou wast alive, was, as I am now, thy faithfull humble Servant. Comfort me a sad, and most sorrowfull Mother, for the death of my daughter, who still was devoted to thee. O Saint, who in Italy, hast restor'd so many dead unto life, free from death my Daughter, the Heiress of the Kingdom thou wast born in.

And pursuing her prayers, with expressions and tears, which would have mov'd a stone to compassion, she entreated so the Saint, that by divine favour he appearing to the Infanta, said thus unto her. Behold O Daughter, by the prayers of thy Mother, God sends me to tell thee, it is at thy choice, to go now to Heaven with me, or for the consolation of the Kingdom, to remain still alive in the World.

Aldonza at these words returning to herself, open'd her eyes with wonder and joy, and seeing her advocate, which none else beheld, humbly answer'd in this manner. Since God, O my blessed
Protector, by thy intercession and means is pleased to give me liberty, to go with thee to Heaven, or remain still on Earth, I refuse not the one, nor dislike of the other. But if for the comfort of my dear and affectionate Mother, thou wouldst have me live a little while longer, I will willingly do so.

Then do so, O my Daughter, St. Anthony replied, and giving her a cord said kiss this cord in witness of thy health, which she taking into her hand, as if she had awaked out of a very great sleep, brake out in this manner. Behold my dear Mother, the glorious St. Anthony gives me his cord to kiss, and together with my life, hath obtained my health. But the Queen seeing no body there, knew her daughter was recover'd by the Saints intercession.
Whereupon all the Kingdom extolling the miracle, the People no less shewed their gladness, in honour of the Saint, then in memory of the favour the Infanta had rec • ived.

So the bonfires, and other signes of joy, which dayly were resplendent, in the testimony of the holiness of our Saint, made every one hope to have a Protector in Heaven, which never would abandon
them. But the Devil, who, like a Serpent, the more he is troden on, the more he is incensed, and angry, omitting no attempt for the gaining of souls, did all in his power, to cause as much ill to mankind, as our Saint had done good.

In Santareno a Village in Portugall resided a Woman, who violating her faith as often to her husband, as she had opportunities of being dishonest, was so shameless in sinning, she supposed not that adultery redounded to her infamy, but rather was a credit, and a grace unto her, making therefore that progress in her sins, that she thought no repentance could cancell them, she began to reflect on the glory of Heaven, and the happiness she had lost, by such vile and wicked courses.

Being sad then, and pensive, and having many tempests in her minde, she was altogether unacquainted with repose. To weep, beat her breast, ask pardon of God, figh, fast, and not sleep, were her daily entertainments, so as grown lean, and meager, she seem'd not the same dissolute person, who before was so beautifull, and merry.

Often at midnight, when silence made the tyrant of Darkness, invaded with sleep
the liberty of her eyes, she seeing in a drea •… all the horrours of hell, was so melancholy and sad, that she thought she could obtain no forgiveness of God, unless in satisfaction of her errours, she made away her self.

Being therefore accustom'd to nourish such thoughts, she mused on nothing, but poysons, knives, halters, precipices, and drownings, but yet in the midst of these frights remembring St. Anthony, to whom she had alwayes been devoted, she earnestly recommended her self to his help and protection.

But the Devil perceiving, she was fairly advanc't in the way of despair, very diligently sollicited the loss of her soul, appearing one day unto her in the form of a crucifix, and shewing her his head crown'd with thornes, his hands, and his feet gor'd with nails, his side pierc't with a lance, his heart distilling water and blood, and his body black and blew, and wounded all over.

Behold he said, O Woman, what I, to redeem thee, have endur'd, and yet thou ingratefull for all this great love, hast not ceased to offend me with thy infinite transgressions. Now since thy offences are incapable of pardon, except by thy death, I love thee so well, because thou
art my Creature, that I come here in person to tell thee, if out of contrition thou wilt drown thy self in Tagus, soon after thy death I'le receive thee into glory.
Having said, he vanisht, and leaving only horrour, and dreadfulness behind him, infected the Air.

Now when the poor woman had seen so strange a vision, we may easily imagine how afflicted she remain'd, who quickly would have follow'd his counsel, if her Angel Guardian withholding her invisibly, she had not thought it best, to deferr it for a while. So while she sigh'd and sob'd, being irresolute what to do, her husband unexpectedly arriving, and enquiring the cause of her sadness was inform'd of all, and hearing the visions of crucifixes, and the counsell that was given her, to go and drown her self, reprov'd her sharply, and telling her she was mad, and possest, put her so into despair, that she went to throw her self into the river.

That day by good fortune, was the feast of St. Anthony, whereupon as she passed that way, I know not by what means, she went into his Church, and kneeling at the Altar, pray'd devoutly to him, that he would reveal it to her, if •… t was the will of God, she should drown
her self, or no. The throngs of the people, which came, and went away, the ornaments, the lights, the musick, and incense should have been sufficient arguments to cheer and encourage her, yet she bathing her prayers with her tears, and looking so pale, and so sad, as would have even soften'd a diamond it self, she so wearyed her self with praying that she falling asleep, heard the Saint speak to her in this manner, look in thy lap for a writing, which as soon as thou hast read, thou shalt be free from all diabolical vexation.

The woman awaking; and finding in her lap the writing aforesaid, saw it was of this tenor, Behold the wood of the Cross, fly ye adverse parties, the Lion of the Tribe of Judah hath o'recome, Alleluja Alleluja.

She no sooner had done reading those words (O wonder of our Saint) but finding her self restored to her former condition, chac't away the extravagant vision, and knew it was only a deceit of the Devil. Whereupon giving thanks to the Saint with the powers of her soul, she returned safe and joyful to her home, and relating the business to her incredulous husband, and shewing him the writing,
did not cease to prayse her advocate.

That heavenly note was an invisible Key, which opening her husbands understanding, made him fully comprehend, that his wife was set at liberty by the miracle of our Saint, so as he going instantly to the King, acquainted him with it, who desirous to see it, made him bring it to him with all speed.

But no sooner the woman was deprived of the paper, which as a white shield made in heaven, defended her from evil, and infernal opppression, but the devill returning upon her, began more then ever to torment her. Her Husband knew the cause of her sufferings, whereupon he humbly begged of the King to restore that holy writing, but could not prevail, for the King having tryed it on some women possest with miraculous effect, preserved it as a relique, and laid it up carefully amongst his choycest things.

This his cruelty to the woman seeming strange unto many, some Fryars of St. Francis repaired to his Majesty to entreat him at least to give her a coppy of the writing, to which he consenting, she no sooner had the same, but with a greater wonder then the former, found her self quite recovered.
Wherefore all giving thanks to the Saint, for the space of twenty years which she afterwards lived very penitently and well, she never more was troubled at all.

But though Portugal assisted in this manner by our Saint, did not make the rest of Europe repine, and envy it, yet Italy still desirous of his favors, the more it received every day, the more thirsted after them.
In Padoua was a building, which seated on the one side: near the famous Physick Garden, and near two noble Churches on the other, the Saints, and St. Justines was commonly called il Maglio.
This Fabrick made the storehouse for the publick defence, besides many pieces of brass, had a very great quantity of powder, which was kept in the bowels of a very strong tower.
O dreadfull seed of death, found out by mans wit, as if the act of dying, grown barren by long use, had wanted fertility to contrive our destruction.

Now the powder taking fire by some accident, sent a great cloud of smoak into the air, which forerunning the destruction that ensu'd, made the Sun mourn for pitty. Two dreadfull claps of thunder following after, which for many
miles together, made deaf the inhabitants, overthrew both the tower, and the buildings, and with the great force of the blow, ruin'd many great houses, and pallaces thereabouts.

To see flie to Heaven, huge stones, long beams, tiles, iron, great planks, Men, and beasts, with many other ponderous implements, and to see, that all these things mixt with smoak, and with dust, like a deluge of destruction, rain'd down on the river, and the neighbouring Monasteries, breaking roofs, and spoiling walls, was to be a Spectator of the end of the World.
The Padouans therefore pale, and halfe dead, had not force to cry out, but immoveable like statues (having paid the first motions to humanity by their tears) fell a running towards the ruines.

And behold (though yet buried in the darkness, and dust) a piazza is presented to their eyes in that place, where a little before many houses appear'd, which in the heaps of timber and Stones, shewed the horrid confusion of the mixture, and posture of things, yet the horrour was as great, as was the destruction, with which it was cover'd.

The cries and tears of them, who bewail'd
their buri'd Parents, and the goods they had lost, (adding misery by this means to the fearfull disaster) made it dreadfuller, and more lamentable.

The Magistrates therefore causing the ruines to be searcht, to fish as it were for dead bodies in a sea whose waves were broken stones, among others crusht to pieces, under a great heap of rubbish six foot high, found two children killed and smothered.
The one was a boy of three years old, whose name was Francis Anthony, the Son of a Cobler, and the other called Mary, a girle of that age, a poor Stone-cutters Daughter.

Being received into the arms of their Parents, who is able to conceive without sorrow, how they wept, and lamented over them! The children in their bosoms had enclos'd their Fathers hearts, so as 'tis not strange, that they grieved without end.

They, carri'd one after another to the Arke of the Saint, with a faith that was able, to remove the very Mountains themselves, after long and earnest prayers, were restored both to life, of which authentick process being made (it happening in the Year 1617. on the 24th. of May) gave accasion to our age of great wonder and devotion▪
